item.title: Artistas que perdimos en 2025, en sus propias palabras
item.description: Robert Redford, Roberta Flack, Diane Keaton y Brian Wilson son algunas de las luminarias culturales que nos dejaron este año.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Cohn

media:content.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Neal Boenzi/The New York Times; Fairchild Archive/Penske Media, via Getty Images; Jack Robinson/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images; Sara Hirakawa for The New York Times; Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Clockwise from top left: Robert Redford, Diane Keaton, Roberta Flack, David Lynch, and Brian Wilson.

item.title: Thailand, Attacking Cambodia, Says Its Target Is the Scam Industry
item.description: Thai warplanes have bombed compounds where people are forced to defraud others online. Rights activists say trafficking victims’ lives are at risk.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Lam Yik Fei
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:description: Pheap Sreymean, 20, worked at a scam center in O’Smach, Cambodia. She said foreign workers were not allowed to leave when the center was attacked.

item.title: El punto débil del Pentágono y los titanes de la IA: necesitan las baterías chinas
item.description: Mientras la guerra se reinventa en Ucrania y Silicon Valley se afana por mantener su liderazgo en IA, el dominio chino de las baterías causa inquietud mucho más allá de la industria automovilística.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi, Brad Plumer and Harry Stevens
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Un centro de datos en Ashburn, Virginia. Las baterías de gran tamaño son fundamentales para proteger el sensible software informático de inteligencia artificial.

item.title: A Vintage Kabul Cinema Finally Falls to Taliban Bulldozers
item.description: Built during a cosmopolitan era in the 1960s, the Ariana closed when the Taliban took power, but it was still standing. Now it’s making way for a shopping mall.
item.dc:creator: Safiullah Padshah and Elian Peltier

media:content.media:credit: Danish Siddiqui/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Watching a Bollywood movie at the Ariana Cinema in Kabul, Afghanistan, in 2012.

item.title: Corrections: Dec. 24, 2025
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Dec. 24, 2025.

item.title: Quote of the Day: YouTube Dominates the Daytime, And Rivals Are Trying to Respond
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, December 24, 2025.

item.title: 19 States Sue to Block White House Plan to End Gender-Related Care for Minors
item.description: The coalition of states seeks to stop a Trump administration effort to cut off federal funding to hospitals that provide such care.
item.dc:creator: Orlando Mayorquín and Chris Hippensteel

media:content.media:credit: Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Letitia James, left, attorney general of New York, at a conference in May with attorneys general from other states including, from left, Rob Bonta of California, Kwame Raoul of Illinois, Keith Ellison of Minnesota and Matt Platkin of New Jersey.

item.title: Mamdani Names Fire Commissioner, but Comments From the Former One Linger
item.description: Zohran Mamdani chose Lillian Bonsignore to be fire commissioner, weeks after the former commissioner, Robert S. Tucker, resigned, citing Mr. Mamdani’s views on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, the mayor-elect of New York City, announced that he had chosen Lillian Bonsignore to be the city’s next fire commissioner.

item.title: The Best Songs of 2025, Part 1
item.description: Jon Caramanica, host of The Times’s “Popcast,” counts down Nos. 10 through 6, from Tate McRae to the XXL Freshman Freestyle, ahead of his top five.
item.dc:creator: Jon Caramanica, Arjun Srivatsa and Joe Coscarelli

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Dec. 24, 2025
item.description: Ella Dershowitz forges ahead.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Judge Blocks Conditions Imposed on States Seeking FEMA Grants
item.description: The Trump administration had sought to require states to account for population losses tied to deportations in order to receive emergency preparedness grants.
item.dc:creator: Scott Dance

media:content.media:credit: Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Residents searched through debris after a tornado passed through London, Ky., in May. Kentucky is one of 11 states that sued over federal efforts to withhold FEMA grants over population counts.

item.title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs’s Lawyers File Appeal, Arguing His Sentence Was Unjust
item.description: The mogul’s lawyers say that a judge issued an excessively steep sentence for prostitution offenses after Mr. Combs was acquitted of more serious charges.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Ben Sisario

media:content.media:credit: Mark Von Holden/Invision, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Sean Combs was convicted of arranging for the travel of male escorts across state lines but acquitted of sex trafficking and racketeering conspiracy.

item.title: A Democrat, a Republican and a Supermarket Baron Go to ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: A “Marty Supreme” showing took a political turn when John Catsimatidis, who has a small role in the movie, invited both Gov. Kathy Hochul and her Republican rival, Bruce Blakeman.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: John Catsimatidis invited Gov. Kathy Hochul to his premiere of “Marty Supreme” in Manhattan.

item.title: Texas Age-Verification Law for App Stores Is Blocked, a Win for Apple and Google
item.description: A preliminary injunction in federal court cited the First Amendment, handing a win to tech companies like Apple and Google.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac

media:content.media:credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Texas’ App Store Accountability Act was set to take effect next month.

item.title: Journey to Antarctica Part 1
item.description: Abandoning ship, negotiating fires or hitting an iceberg are all risks when traveling to one of the fastest-melting glaciers on the continent. Our science reporter Raymond Zhong shares a glimpse into the survival training for his upcoming Antarctic trip.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong, Christina Thornell, Kassie Bracken, Leila Medina, Jon Miller, Edward Vega, Stephanie Swart, Nikolay Nikolov and Phil Caller

item.title: Journey to the Melting Continent
item.description: The New York Times is joining an expedition by sea to Antarctica’s fastest-thinning glaciers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Lawmaker Returns to Migrant Center Where She Clashed With U.S. Agents
item.description: Representative LaMonica McIver, a New Jersey Democrat, called on immigration officials to close Delaney Hall in Newark, calling detainees’ food and medical care inadequate.
item.dc:creator: Mark Bonamo

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: From left, Representatives Robert Menendez, LaMonica McIver and Yvette Clarke denounced conditions at Delaney Hall, a federal immigration detention center, after visiting it on Tuesday.

item.title: Palm Beach Rallies Behind a Restaurant Manager Held at ‘Alligator Alcatraz’
item.description: After nearly two weeks in detention, José Gonzalez, the popular host of an upscale restaurant, returns home.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay

item.title: Un reportaje de ‘60 Minutes’ fue retirado del aire. Ahora circula en internet
item.description: A último momento, CBS News detuvo un segmento sobre hombres venezolanos deportados por el gobierno de Donald Trump a una prisión en El Salvador. Aun así, el reportaje terminó apareciendo en línea.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

media:content.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El programa 60 Minutes de la CBS es visto por una media de 10 millones de espectadores a la semana.

item.title: Las incautaciones de buques realizadas por EE. UU. estancan la industria petrolera venezolana
item.description: Los puertos de Venezuela se están llenando de petroleros, ya que las autoridades temen sacarlos en aguas internacionales y ponerlos en el punto de mira de Estados Unidos.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Imagen de satélite 2025 Vantor, vía Reuters
media:content.media:description: Desde que el 10 de diciembre fuera incautado el Skipper, un petrolero que transportaba petróleo venezolano, solo dos buques que transportaban crudo parecen haber intentado navegar más allá de las aguas de Venezuela.

item.title: U.S. Bars 5 European Tech Regulators and Researchers
item.description: The Trump administration, citing “foreign censorship,” imposed travel bans on experts involved in monitoring major tech platforms.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said in a statement that five Europeans “have led organized efforts to coerce American platforms to censor, demonetize and suppress American viewpoints they oppose.”

item.title: Redacted Material in Some Epstein Files Is Easily Recovered
item.description: The ease of recovering information that was not properly redacted digitally suggests that at least some of the documents released by the Justice Department were hastily censored.
item.dc:creator: Santul Nerkar

media:content.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera Pichardo for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The executors of Jeffrey Epstein’s estate faced a civil suit filed in the Virgin Islands in 2021. Documents from the suit released late Monday included some that were not properly redacted digitally. Above, the court in 2020.

item.title: Mamdani Named His Fire Commissioner. Then Adams Did Too.
item.description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani chose Lillian Bonsignore, the former chief of New York’s E.M.S., as the first openly gay person to lead the Fire Department.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays

media:content.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani announced that Lillian Bonsignore, who retired from the New York Fire Department in 2022, was his pick to be the city’s next fire commissioner.

item.title: Youth Hostels, Blood Banks, Yoga: How One Far-Right Network Spread Across the World
item.description: Far-right mobilization is not an inevitable consequence of the precariousness of our times.
item.dc:creator: Felix Pal

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez/The New York Times

item.title: Democratic Governors Are Fighting Trump’s War on Wind Energy
item.description: Leaders in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Rhode Island are racing to save offshore wind farms targeted by the president.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman, Benjamin Oreskes and Maxine Joselow

media:content.media:credit: Bob O'Connor for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Tower sections for the Vineyard Wind offshore wind farm in New Bedford, Mass., one of five wind projects halted by the Trump administration on Monday.

item.title: Robert Nakamura, ‘Godfather’ of Asian American Film, Dies at 88
item.description: In his work, he often returned to Manzanar, the camp in which he and his family, along with thousands of other people of Japanese descent, were interned during World War II.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman

item.title: Officers Who Failed N.Y.P.D. Mental Health Exams Can Stay
item.description: The city and the union agreed to a 12-month probation for 30 officers. The department had moved to fire them after they failed psychological exams or background checks.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer

media:content.media:credit: Vincent Alban/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Police Department has been struggling with an exodus of officers.

item.title: Justices Block National Guard Deployment in Chicago
item.description: Also, economic growth surged through the summer. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Is Adding to Its Military Buildup in the Caribbean
item.description: Over the past week, C-17 heavy-lift cargo planes, which usually transport troops and equipment, flew to Puerto Rico at least 16 times, according to flight tracking data reviewed by The New York Times.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert and Helene Cooper

media:content.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Ground crews unloaded cargo last week from an Air Force C-17 Globemaster III aircraft, top, parked next to a U.S. Air Force HC-130 aircraft, at the Roosevelt Roads naval base in Ceiba, Puerto Rico.

item.title: Suspect in Brown University Shooting Worked in Portugal After Leaving University
item.description: One friend said Claudio Neves Valente appeared to live a detached life, upset that “he couldn’t be the genius he thought he should be.”
item.dc:creator: Anemona Hartocollis and Azam Ahmed

media:content.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A memorial was set up outside the Van Wickle Gates at Brown University.

item.title: National Guard Troops to Arrive in New Orleans
item.description: The troops will join an existing wave of Border Patrol agents, months after Gov. Jeff Landry first suggested that the National Guard could help tamp down on crime in Louisiana.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Kathleen Flynn for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Members of the National Guard will join Border Patrol agents who have already been in New Orleans since early December as part of a federal crackdown on undocumented immigration.

item.title: Trump’s Tanker Crackdown Paralyzes Venezuelan Oil Exports
item.description: Oil exports, the country’s financial lifeblood, have plummeted after the United States took action against three ships that have been used to carry its crude.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Rebecca F. Elliott
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Satellite Image 2025 Vantor, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: Since the Skipper, a tanker carrying Venezuelan oil, was seized on Dec. 10, only two tankers carrying crude appear to have tried to sail beyond Venezuela’s waters.

item.title: Trooper Killed at Motor Vehicle Office in Delaware
item.description: Deputies responded to a report of an active shooter at the Division of Motor Vehicles office in Wilmington, Del., the authorities said. The gunman has also died, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz

media:content.media:credit: abc7ny
media:content.media:description: Local news reports showed a heavy police presence on Tuesday after a shooting at a Division of Motor Vehicles office in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Woman Dies in East Harlem When Scaffolding Collapses After Truck Crash
item.description: A garbage truck hit a parked vehicle, pushing it into the scaffolding, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Latson

media:content.media:credit: Beata Zawrzel/NurPhoto, via Associated Press

item.title: Looking Back at a Historic Year of Dismantling Climate Policies
item.description: The Trump administration has aggressively pulled America away from its global role in climate and environmental research, diplomacy, regulation and investment.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

media:content.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Trump administration has weakened a host of agencies and environmental practices in its first year.

item.title: Libyan Military’s Chief of Staff and 4 Others Are Killed in Plane Crash in Turkey
item.description: The internationally recognized government of Libya confirmed the deaths of Lt. Gen. Mohamed Ali Ahmed al-Haddad, the army chief of general staff, and other officers flying home after a meeting in Turkey.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni, Safak Timur and Islam Al-Atrash

media:content.media:credit: Turkish Defense Ministry
media:content.media:description: A photograph released by the Turkish Defense Ministry showing the Libyan Army chief of the general staff, Lt. Gen. Mohamed Ali Ahmed al-Haddad, in Ankara, Turkey on Tuesday.

item.title: Pennsylvania Nursing Home Explosion Kills 2
item.description: A resident and an employee were killed after two explosions at the Bristol Health and Rehab Center resulted in a large fire and partial collapse of the building, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hippensteel, Rylee Kirk, Pooja Salhotra, Mark Bonamo and Francesca Regalado

media:content.media:credit: Bastiaan Slabbers/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A gas explosion at a nursing home in Bristol, Pa., drew a large emergency response on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: Dating ChatGPT
item.description: The bot has been marketed as a general-purpose tool that can write code, summarize documents and give advice. But can it be a good boyfriend?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

media:content.media:credit: Helen Orr for The New York Times

item.title: Supreme Court Refuses to Allow Trump to Deploy National Guard in Chicago
item.description: President Trump ordered state-based troops to Portland, Ore.; Los Angeles; Washington; and Chicago over the objections of state and local officials.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The president’s efforts to use troops for domestic policing have prompted legal challenges accusing the Trump administration of exceeding its authority.

item.title: Pulled ’60 Minutes’ Report, Briefly Streamed in Canada, Is All Over the Internet Now
item.description: At the last minute, CBS News held a segment about Venezuelan men who were deported by the Trump administration to a prison in El Salvador. It surfaced online anyway.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Grynbaum

media:content.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: CBS’s “60 Minutes” is seen by an average of 10 million viewers a week.

item.title: Zelensky Calls Peace Plan ‘Quite Solid,’ Russia Then Launches Missiles
item.description: Tuesday morning, hours after President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that the latest American-backed proposals for a peace deal between Kyiv and Moscow looked “quite solid,” Russia launched a series of drone and missiles strikes against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Leventhal

media:content.media:credit: Roman Pilipey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Workers clearing debris from the roof of a heavily damaged residential building following a drone strike in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: ¿Notaste ese desfase de 5 millonésimas de segundo en tu reloj? Te explicamos qué pasó
item.description: Algunos de los relojes atómicos más precisos de EE. UU. sufrieron una leve interrupción luego de que fuertes vientos en Colorado provocaran la falla de un generador.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Adeel Hassan

media:content.media:credit: R. Eskalis/Instituto Nacional de Normas y Tecnología
media:content.media:description: Un reloj de fuente de cesio en el Instituto Nacional de Estándares y Tecnología de Boulder, Colorado.

item.title: Pro-Trump Influencers Stay Conspicuously Quiet About Epstein Files
item.description: Their silence contrasted with the uproar made over the weekend when the Justice Department’s first release focused on former President Bill Clinton.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump was mentioned multiple times in the documents the Justice Department released about Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: U.S. Takes a Step Toward Approving Seabed Mining in International Waters
item.description: The federal government said it would hold hearings next month on controversial applications to mine the ocean floor.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

media:content.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A ship chartered by the Metals Company in 2021 to assess the potential of seabed mining.

item.title: France Fails to Adopt a Budget by Year’s End. Again.
item.description: French lawmakers passed a special law on Tuesday to avoid a shutdown until a budget is adopted. Negotiations will resume in January.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic

media:content.media:credit: Thomas Samson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu of France, speaking in Parliament on Tuesday, now has a few more weeks to reach a deal.

item.title: A 3-D Look Inside Trump’s Revamped Oval Office
item.description: Take a 3-D tour of the president’s office, where he covered more than a third of wall space with gold.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu, Doug Mills, Junho Lee, Marco Hernandez, Katie Rogers and Mika Gröndahl

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Man Charged With Hate Crime in Attack Near Chabad Headquarters
item.description: Authorities say that Armani Charles, 23, accosted a man on the street before a running argument devolved into a stabbing.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The attack took place just steps from the headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitch movement in Brooklyn.

item.title: Se enamoró de ChatGPT. Y luego lo eliminó
item.description: La mujer de 29 años que creó la comunidad “MyBoyfriendIsAI” en Reddit ya no pasa tiempo (ni intercambia mensajes) con su novio creado con inteligencia artificial. Ha encontrado algo más satisfactorio.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill

media:content.media:credit: Helen Orr para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: “¿Cómo se supone que voy a confiar en sus consejos ahora si solo va a decir que sí a todo?”, dijo Ayrin sobre su novio generado por chatbot tras un cambio de software.

item.title: Oklahoma Instructor Mel Curth Who Failed Student Samantha Fulnecky’s Gender Essay Is Fired
item.description: The instructor, a graduate student at the University of Oklahoma, gave a zero to a student who wrote an essay arguing in favor of traditional gender definitions based on biblical teachings.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel

media:content.media:credit: Doug Hoke/The Oklahoman, via Reuters
media:content.media:description: The University of Oklahoma campus in Norman, Okla.
